text:
REBECCA KARP: Imagine a
world in which machine

learning algorithms can
identify suspicious lesions

on mammograms previously
unidentified by human doctors,

thereby improving early
detection of breast cancer.
We live in that world.

I'm amazed by the promise
digital technologies hold

to improve the quality of
health and the cost of care.

And while such technologies
offer unequivocal potential,

less than 7% of organizations
have adopted them.
Why is this the case?

Through research with hundreds
of entrepreneurs, providers,

and payers, I've
learned it's not

because these technologies
do not solve real problems.

Rather, it's because
implementing these innovations

can provoke disruption
and require new skills.

It's the prospect
of implementation
that holds up adoption and use.

Organizations can overcome
implementation challenges

when they strategically pace the
deployment of such technologies

in ways that alleviate fears
and provide opportunities
for upskilling.
[MUSIC FADING]
